Pictogram ( è±¡å½¢ ): a nose â€” original form of é¼» ( OC *blids , â€œnoseâ€). Later phonetically borrowed as an instance of jiajie ( å‡å€Ÿ ) for è‡ª ( OC *É¦ljids , â€œoneself; fromâ€).
Folk etymology considers the meaning to arise from a habit of pointing at oneâ€™s nose to indicate oneself.

[ç™½]
Unclear; probably a pictogram ( è±¡å½¢ ).
Guo (1954) suggests that it represents a thumb and is original form of æ‹‡ ( *mÉ¯Ê” ) or, more probably, æ“˜ ( *preËÉ¡ ) .
Alternatively, Unger ( apud Schuessler, 2007) suggests that it represents an acorn, noting its use in æ¨‚ / ä¹ ( â€œ oak â€ ) (= æ«Ÿ / æ  ) and çš‚ ( zÃ o , â€œ acorn â€ ) . In this interpretation, the meaning of â€œwhiteâ€ is derived from the color of an acorn's inside. Unrelated to the top component of åŸ .

[æ—¥]
Pictogram ( è±¡å½¢ ) â€“ the sun. A dot or line was added in the centre to distinguish it from visually similar characters, e.g. å›— (early form of ä¸ ). Compare earlier forms of the character with the astronomical and astrological symbol for the Sun ( â˜‰ ) and the Egyptian hieroglyph ğ“‡³ .
